awd_abstract_narration:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) is pleased to announce the selection of Mung Chiang , the Arthur LeGrand Doty Professor of Electrical Engineering at Princeton University, to receive its 2013 Alan T. Waterman Award. Dr. Chiang is also an associated faculty of Computer Science and an affiliated faculty of the Department of Applied and Computational Mathematics at Princeton.

The Waterman Award is the National Science Foundation's (NSF) highest honor. The annual award recognizes outstanding researchers under the age of 35 in any field of science or engineering that NSF supports. In addition to a medal, this year's awardee will receive a $1 million grant over a five-year period for further advanced study in his field.

Professor Chiang, is the founder of the Princeton EDGE Lab, which bridges over the theory-practice divide in networking through collaboration across many disciplinary boundaries as well as the academia-industry boundary. His team constantly re-examines the mathematical crystallization of engineering artifacts in networking.  His research investigates an evolving set of projects spanning the modeling, analysis, and design of networks, both technological and human ones. Prof. Chiang also received the 2012 IEEE Kiyo Tomiyasu Award -for demonstrating the practicality of a new theoretical foundation for the analysis and design of communication networks', a U.S. Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers in 2008, an Office of Naval Research Young Investigator Award in 2007, and a National Science Foundation CAREER Award in 2005. He was named as an MIT Technology Review TR35 Young Innovator in 2007, and was elected an IEEE Fellow in 2012.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The Waterman Award enabled us to conduct innovative research not typically supported by other grants, particularly in the fields of social-economic networks, to bridge the theory-practice divide in networking through collaboration across multiple disciplinary boundaries and the academia-industry boundary. In particular, we investigated an increasing set of initiatives encompassing the modeling, analysis, and design of networks, both technological and human, in smart data pricing, social learning networks, and dispersive AI and edge computing in the context of 5G networks. Our study resulted in over thirty articles in prestigious journals, books, and conference proceedings. It was also disseminated through a number of keynote addresses, and it spawned a number of start-ups. Important intellectual merit and larger impact are outlined in depth in this reports summary.

Intellectual Merit:

(1) Smart data pricing

  • Cloud bidding: Our cloud bidding project centered on the cloud provider's method for establishing spot prices and user bidding strategies. Compared to on-demand pricing, we discovered that spot pricing cuts user costs by 90% with only a slight increase in completion time.
  • Cloud virtual service provider: We evaluated the viability of an intermediary, the cloud virtual service provider (CVSP), that rents cloud resources from a CSP and resells them to consumers. We demonstrated that the CVSP's business model is only sustainable if the average job runtimes and sustained-use discount thresholds are sufficiently low; otherwise, the CVSP cannot simultaneously maintain low job waiting times and sustained-use discount eligibility.  
  • Traded data plans: We analyzed a secondary data market in which users can buy and sell unused data caps. ISPs are able to match buyers and sellers in order to enhance their profits due to the fact that various buyers and sellers are ready to bid different prices for varying volumes of data. 

(2) Social learning networks

  • Individualization: We have devised a system that we refer to as the Mobile Integrated and Individualized Course, or MIIC for short. MIIC is a tailored course delivery platform that blends four modalities of learning - lecture videos, text, tests, and social learning - into a single mobile app, and collects fine-grained behavioral measures about each student as they interact with the course material.
  • Clickstream analytics: We utilized millions of clickstream logs generated by tens of thousands of students enrolled in our MOOCs. The quality of these behavior-based algorithms was superior to more typical collaborative filtering techniques that depend purely on previous quiz performance. 
  • Social learning efficiency: We created a framework for determining the efficacy of an SLN by comparing the user benefit in the observed network to a benchmark representing the greatest utility that may be achieved through optimization. Our framework determined the optimal SLN by maximizing utility according to a set of constraints inferrable from the network. 
  • Engagement modeling: We proposed a probabilistic model for inferring a learner's level of involvement by treating it as a latent variable that influences the learner's performance and is in turn influenced by the learner's behavior. Using cross-validation, we discovered that our model outperforms two existing state-of-the-art methods in predicting unobserved learner responses to quiz questions.
  • Personalized thread recommendations for MOOC: Using point processes, we provided a probabilistic model for the process of learners posting on such forums. We developed a framework that employs a unique linear estimator to provide guidelines on the amount of items and responses necessary to achieve minimal estimation errors in tests or surveys. We provided a new perspective on these well-established binary regression methods by demonstrating that linearizing the probit model in combination with linear estimators performs comparably to state-of-the-art nonlinear regression methods.

(3) Dispersive AI and edge computing in 5G networks

  • Massive machine-type communications: We presented UL random access protocols utilizing pseudo-random beamforming to create UL IoT multiple access systems that can take advantage of MIMO advantages with low complexity and low overhead. We developed joint beam selection and random access schemes that can provably achieve fractions of the optimal capacity region with low overhead regardless of the number of interfering devices.
  • Reliable edge and coded computing: We concentrated on resolving response time variability caused by anomalous system behavior. We investigated solutions to the performance and scalability issues of MDS-based coded computing. We proposed addressing these issues by developing error-correcting-code-inspired techniques that outperform for matrix-vector multiplication, a critical step in many data analysis algorithms.

Broader Impact: Our study on smart data pricing has a significant effect on network economics and data analytics. It impacts the fields of economics, social science, psychology, and behavior studies. Second, our research on social learning networks has significant implications for learning technologies, social networking, and machine learning. MOOC has touched over 250,000 people worldwide, including students and industry professionals. Our research on dispersed AI and edge computing in 5G has a principal impact on the internet of things and large-scale distributed computing at the network's edge.
